reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 7, 2020
reviews.reviewText: I bought three of these cameras for use live streaming church services. They work very well for this purpose as I needed to get a closer view in a large room and a regular wide-angle webcam would not work for this need. The cameras have a metal body and lens housing, are relatively heavy and look to be well made. They also produce the 1080p 30fps video I need for the OBS software that I use.The cameras have a 1/4" thread mount hole on both the top and bottom, which allows them to be "stacked" in a fixed mounting set-up, taking up a pretty small footprint.Both the zoom and focus adjustments are touchy (very little movement makes a big change), but these both can be locked in once the desired setting is achieved. There is also an aperture adjustment. The cameras work well together in the OBS software along with a standard webcam and a video capture card (which captures video from a camcorder).The white balance looks slightly different between the three cameras I purchased, but I was able to adjust this in the OBS software.Overall, very pleased with the purchase.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2020
reviews.reviewTitle: 4.0 out of 5 stars Not a bad little camera
reviews.reviewText: This is actually kind of a neat little camera.The first thing I noticed what that it has some "heft" to it. It doesn't feel like a cheapie webcam with a lightweight plastic or tiny sliver-of-glass lens. This thing has a real lens and a solid metal case. The lens is interchangeable too, so if you want to get a different field of view, you should be able to find a replacement.It has manual zoom, manual focus and manual aperture. It's "varifocal", which means as you zoom, the focus will go out and you will need to readjust. Don't expect to use it as a quick-zoom hand held camera. It is intended to be mounted permanently and just use the zoom to set the frame. Once you get it set the way you want it, the zoom and focus can be locked in place with the screw knobs.What I didn't expect was the range of focus. This thing can essentially function as a macro, with the focusing down to less than an inch (description claims 5mm) when zoomed out and less than a foot at it's longest zoom. This allows for a field of view as little as 1-2" across. Neat if you wanted to use it to do some extreme close-up shots.It comes with quite a long cord, which for this type of camera is good. I have it attached to a monitor which is mounted up near the ceiling quite a ways away from the computer it is plugged in to. There is ample cord to get there. I didn't measure, but it has to be at least 10' long, maybe more.It has two standard 1/4x20 threaded holes - one in the top and one in the bottom. The curious thing though is that it comes with a package of screws and plastic wall anchors, but no mounting bracket of any kind. It seems like there should be some sort of bracket, but the box doesn't seem big enough to even fit one so it's a little bizarre that they include screws. Fortunately I have a pile of miscellaneous GoPro parts laying around so I ended up using a 1/4x20 to GoPro adapter and a standard GoPro stick-on mount.Note: There is an allen key for removing the lens in the package with the screws so don't just throw it away!The image quality is decent enough for something in this class. Nothing to write home about, but much better than the cheapie cameras of a few years ago. The adjustable aperture lets you tailor to the environment you are in.I think the best application for this kind of camera is probably for video conferencing where you want to set up multiple cameras each pointing to a specific seat around a table. This is where the zoom and relatively long focal length comes in handy. You can mount it on a wall across the room and zoom in on a particular seat.All in all a decent little camera for the money.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on December 16, 2020
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Good image quality, but not by default on Win7
reviews.reviewText: This review is for the version of the camera with the OV2710 sensor and 5-50mm varifocal lens.Using 64bit Windows 7 Pro, with no special drivers, you can plug this camera into a USB port and "it just works". However, if you fire up Zoom, Discord, or Microsoft Teams and look at the live camera image, you may be disappointed. Low resolution and terribly underexposed (dark) even with the lens aperture all the way open.The camera is capable of much better performance, and fortunately, there's an easy fix if you have this disappointing experience. Get a copy of the free OBS (Open Broadcaster Software) application. Start it running, create a scene and use this camera as the video input. Then create a virtual camera in OBS. In Zoom, Discord, etc., select the OBS virtual camera. Wow! Higher resolution, wider frame format, and proper exposure.I am not expert on USB video protocols, but I believe the camera is coming up in a default "works with anything" mode, and the typical videochat app doesn't know how to command the camera into its more capable modes. OBS does whatever is needed to get a nice image out of the camera. In other operating systems, or more recent versions of Windows, it's possible that this is handled by the OS. But if you're stuck with Win7, there's this easy and free way to get nice video from this camera.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on October 14, 2020
reviews.reviewTitle: 1.0 out of 5 stars Don’t buy this
reviews.reviewText: A potato can shoot a better video. It is horrible in a normal office lighting. There is no easy way to adjust any settings on a Mac.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on August 5, 2020
reviews.reviewText: I left an honest review about the problems with this camera, but Amazon blocked it. I guess they don't want honest reviews unless they are positive. There is nothing positive about my experience with this camera. Poor image quality, poor customer support.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 23, 2021
reviews.reviewTitle: 5.0 out of 5 stars Excellent camera to magnify small parts
reviews.reviewText: I'm using it with the Python OpenCV on a Raspberry Pi. Raspberry Pi automatically recognizes it as a camera which is nice. Color accuracy is poor, but I'm using it for inspection on an automated electronics assembly process. The image shows an 0402 SMT footprint with .2 and .1mm traces. Work well for this application, much better than the other cameras pitched as 'microscopes' (they have too much zoom).Camera seems durable. Zoom and focus rings are tight. It's nice that you can lock them.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on June 5, 2020
reviews.reviewTitle: 3.0 out of 5 stars A good value for the cost, image looks okay, but not very light sensitive
reviews.reviewText: This maybe due to the level of zoom range with a small amount of glass in the lens. It does load automatically with Win 10 no extra drivers needed.

reviews.reviewDate: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2019
reviews.reviewText: I'm actually interested in several uses for this camera. I wanted something with fairly good sensitivity to low light, so I settled on the 2mp camera. I have say I'm impressed! I think the lenses alone are probably worth the price, excellent resolution, good frame rate and you can go from a wide field of view to telephoto with ease. It also has excellent image quality up close, like a low mag microscope. This camera is highly recommended, well worth the money.
Awesome camera, good quality all around.I needed one that you could manually focus as I am keeping an eye on some ant pets of mine. It makes for crystal clear giant ants on the big screen lol!
